title: How to Practice Good Selfie Etiquette

steps.headline: Think about your location and surroundings.
steps.description:
There are certain times and locations where others will consider selfie-taking rude, disrespectful, or otherwise antisocial. You should avoid taking selfies here like the plague. Here are some examples:
Funerals and memorials (too solemn)
Bathroom toilet (distasteful)
Driving (too reckless)

steps.headline: Use a pose that flatters you.
steps.description: What you think looks right might not to other people. Ask for a second opinion before posting it everywhere.

steps.headline: Practice good hygiene and try to look your best.
steps.description: You don't want to get a shot with something stuck in your teeth. If you're going to be taking a picture of yourself, you might as well look your best.

steps.headline: Limit the number of times you post selfies.
steps.description: If you frequently add or change pictures, it can annoy others and they may begin to see you as narcissistic and in need of attention.

steps.headline: Don't over-use filters.
steps.description: They can look okay occasionally, but using them too much makes it seem like you're trying too hard. Black and white/sepia may be useful if the colors surrounding you are too distracting or you have facial features that don't benefit from vibrant color (like acne).

steps.headline: Write something interesting to go along with your selfie.
steps.description:
This gives anyone who comes across your photo something to enjoy or be entertained by. Here are some ideas:
A story about where you are (if you're on a trip/away from home)
Something new that has changed in your life (picture with your new car/pet/house/weight loss)
A new item of clothing you really like (especially if someone gifted it to you)
A famous quote that summarizes something about what you're thinking/expressing/doing/wearing.
